title: My Weird Winter Skin Fix: That Bourbon Vanilla Tallow Balm
body:
Okay so look. My skin gets angry in winter. Like, flaky, tight, itchy angry. It’s a whole thing. I’d tried the expensive stuff, the drugstore stuff, the weird green bottles from that fancy store. Nothing really stuck. Then I was scrolling on my phone one night, the cat was judging me from the armrest, and I fell into this internet hole about tallow balm. Beef tallow. For your face. I know. It sounded absolutely nuts. But my grandma used to talk about using simple things, and I was desperate. So I ordered this Whipped Tallow Balm in Bourbon Vanilla from this little Etsy shop. I figured, worst case, I’m out thirty bucks and have a weird story.

It arrived in this simple jar. Smelled like vanilla maybe? Or not. Something. Not like dessert, more like… an old book with a vanilla candle nearby. I was skeptical. Putting beef fat on my face felt like a prank I was playing on myself. But my knuckles were cracking, so I went for it.

## How Beef Tallow for Skin Became My Thing

Here’s the history bit I fell into. People have been using animal fats on their skin for, like, forever. Centuries. Millennia. It wasn’t a fancy trend, it was just what worked. Tallow from grass-fed cows is structurally really close to the oils our own skin makes. Our skin recognizes it. It’s not some alien chemical, it’s just… fat. Nutrient-dense fat. My coffee’s getting cold. Anyway, it fell out of fashion when big companies started making stuff in labs with long ingredient lists. Simplicity got boring, I guess. But now it’s having a moment again. A natural skincare comeback. Because sometimes the old ways are the old ways for a reason.

I get why it sounds gross. I did too. But the logic, once you push past the “ew” factor, kind of makes sense. If your skin barrier is wrecked, why not feed it something it actually knows how to use?

## What This Bourbon Vanilla Stuff Actually Does

So the first night I used it, I was just trying to fix my hands. The texture was weird. Not bad weird. It’s whipped, so it’s light but dense? It melts as soon as it touches your skin. Doesn’t just sit there like a greasy film. It goes in. My hands felt… calm. That’s the only word. Not shiny, not sticky, just calm. The dry, tight feeling was gone in like ten minutes.

I got braver. Used it on my face before bed. Woke up and my skin wasn’t screaming for moisture. It was just quiet. Normal. That hadn’t happened in months. Maybe years.

The scent is the real star, though. They call it Bourbon Vanilla. It’s not sweet. It’s warm. Cozy. Like the opposite of stress. When I put it on at night, it’s this whole little ritual that just… turns my brain off for a second. It’s comforting in a way I didn’t know a skincare product could be. It’s not perfume-y. It just smells good and simple.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of This Experiment

I’ve been using it for a month now. Through this gross, dry winter. My elbows haven’t been this smooth since… I don’t know when. High school? The persistent dry patch on my cheek is just gone. Vanished. I didn’t do anything else different.

Here’s the thing about traditional tallow skincare—it doesn’t promise miracles. It just works. It’s deeply, stupidly hydrating. It’s like it gives my skin what it’s been trying to ask for but I was giving it the wrong language. All those complex serums with twenty ingredients were just noise. This is the signal.

I even used it on a minor patch of psoriasis on my leg. Not a cure, obviously, but it soothed the heck out of it. Made it less angry. Less itchy.

## Would I Buy This Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. I already did. I’m on my second jar. I got one for my mom too, who has even drier skin than me and is deeply suspicious of everything. She called me last week and was like, “What is this magic beef jar?” She loves it.

I found the Etsy shop, Malti, when I was searching. The balm is made in France from grass-fed beef suet. It feels small-batch. Thoughtful. Not corporate. That mattered to me. I like knowing where the stuff I put on my body comes from.

It’s not a miracle cure-all. It’s a fantastic moisturizer. A barrier repairer. A winter survival tool. For dry skin, for winter damage, for just needing your skin to feel like skin again.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Weirdly, yes. Because it’s so similar to our skin’s own sebum, it absorbs really well and doesn’t just clog stuff up. It feeds your skin barrier. My face loves it, which I did not see coming.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
For me, no. And I can get clogged pores. It absorbs deep instead of sitting on top. It’s non-comedogenic. But everyone’s skin is different, so maybe patch test.

**What does Bourbon Vanilla tallow balm smell like?**
It’s warm. Cozy. Like vanilla but not from a bakery. More grown-up. Smells like comfort. It’s the best part of the whole experience, honestly.

Anyway. If your skin is being difficult, if winter is beating you up, this might be worth a shot. It’s a simple, old-school solution that just… works. I don’t know what else to say. My skin’s happy, I’m happy. That’s all I wanted.
